We investigate the effect of multiplying the original signal by an exponential function \\( f(t) = e^{at}g(t) \\), where \\( g(t) \\) is the original signal and \\( a \\) is a real number.

If an intervention occurs by filtering the signal with a transformation \\( h(t) \\) at time \\( t_1 \\), will the new Laplace Transform \\( H(s) \\) of the resultant signal solely depend on \\( F(s) \\) rather than the original \\( G(s) \\) and \\( a \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with the filter \\( h(t) \\) creates a convolution effect in time domain, corresponding to a multiplication in the s-domain. This alters the resultant Laplace Transform to depend on the convolutive integration between \\( e^{at}g(t) \\) and \\( h(t) \\), making it influenced by \\( G(s) \\), \\( a \\), and the characteristics of \\( h(t) \\).
